title: 2. System Boundary and Context Boundary
body: The concept of "System Boundaries" acts as the defining perimeter of a software system, marking the boundary between what's inside and what's outside. Understanding these boundaries is essential for effective requirement gathering and project scope definition. Beyond the system, the context boundary separates the internal workings from the external environment. This section will explore how this critical boundary influences project requirements and scope. Understanding context boundaries is essential for maintaining clarity in complex software projects, as they define the borders of responsibility and interaction.

title: 3. Types of Requirements
body: In this part of the lecture, we will dive into the diverse categories that govern software development, including functional and non-functional requirements. Understanding these types is key to crafting well-rounded, effective systems. As we unravel the intricacies, you'll appreciate how each requirement type contributes to the overall success of a project.

title: 2. Classification
body: Diving into different types of traceability, we explore pre-traceability, which involves establishing connections from requirement artefacts to various aspects across four context facets: subject, usage, IT system, and development. Post-traceability shifts our focus to relationships between requirement artefacts and their successors, offering insights into how project elements evolve. The traceability among requirements examines their interconnectedness, unveiling relationships such as refinement, generalisation, or replacement. This classification provides a nuanced understanding of the intricate web of connections within the project.

title: 3. Documentation
body: Documenting traces is pivotal in maintaining a clear and comprehensive record of requirement relationships. This involves employing various techniques, each serving a unique purpose. Textual references offer a written narrative of connections, hyperlinks provide digital shortcuts for quick access, traceability models present visual representations for clarity, matrices offer structured overviews, and graphs provide intuitive depictions. These diverse methods ensure that the complex relationships between requirements are well-documented and easily accessible, fostering effective traceability throughout the requirements engineering process.

title: 2. Change Management
body: Within Requirements Engineering, change management navigates the currents of adjustments and updates to the project's foundational plan. The triggers for these changes are diverse—perhaps a nuanced understanding emerges, or external factors necessitate a shift in scope. This section guides you through how to manage these changes, offering a systematic lens to interpret the evolving narrative. It serves as the architect's blueprint, ensuring changes resonate harmoniously with the project's overarching design.

title: 3. Summary
body: Navigating the complexities of managing requirements in elaborate projects is paramount because those requirements can undergo changes. Change management is more than just a process—it's an established mechanism for handling these changes.

title: L00 - Lecture Recording
body: Here you can find the recording of the first lecture of the current semester: Winter Semester 2024/25

title: 2. Conflict Management
body: In this section, we will define the critical concepts during the Requirements Engineering process and explore different types of requirements that play a crucial role in software development. Understanding these diverse requirements is essential for effectively managing and designing software systems.

title: 3. Summary
body: In this section, we will delve into the systematic steps and methodologies involved in gathering, analyzing, documenting, and managing requirements. This practical knowledge will equip you with the skills needed to navigate the Requirements Engineering process successfully.

title: 2. Ambiguity
body: Ambiguity within requirements documentation presents a challenge due to unclear or imprecise language. This ambiguity can result in misinterpretations, misunderstandings, and pitfalls during system development. Addressing ambiguity becomes crucial to ensure that all stakeholders maintain a standard and precise understanding of the requirements, thereby mitigating the risk of errors and elevating the overall quality of the software development process.

title: 3. Guidelines
body: Guidelines emerge as a critical tool in navigating the challenges posed by ambiguity in requirements documentation. They establish a structured framework for the clear, consistent, and unambiguous expression of requirements. For instance, a guideline may recommend using specific terminology and incorporating measurable criteria in each requirement.

title: 2. Requirements Engineering Overview
body: In this section, we will define the critical concepts during the Requirements Engineering process and explore different types of requirements that play a crucial role in software development. Understanding these diverse requirements is essential for effectively managing and designing software systems.

title: 3. Requirements Engineering Process
body: In this section, we will delve into the systematic steps and methodologies involved in gathering, analyzing, documenting, and managing requirements. This practical knowledge will equip you with the skills needed to navigate the Requirements Engineering process successfully.

title: 2. Requirement Sources
body: In this video, we embark on a journey into the multifaceted origins of requirements. These sources encompass a rich spectrum, ranging from the voices of stakeholders, end-users, and domain experts to the reservoirs of existing documentation, regulatory frameworks, and the wealth of insights gleaned from market research. Gaining an intimate understanding of these sources is pivotal for steering a comprehensive and all-encompassing elicitation process. We delve into the art of identifying and prioritizing these sources, ensuring that no requirement remains overlooked or underappreciated.

title: 3. Elicitation Techniques
body: In this video, we embark on a comprehensive journey through the diverse landscape of elicitation techniques, which serve as the tools and methods for extracting requirements with precision and effectiveness. We look over the strengths and weaknesses inherent in each technique, offering insights into when and where to apply them and arming you with the discernment needed to select the most appropriate method for your unique project context.

title: 7. Observation Technique
body: Sometimes, stakeholders may not be able to articulate their needs or may not even be aware of them. In such cases, observation techniques come to the rescue. In this video, we'll explore the power of direct observation, contextual inquiry, and ethnographic studies in understanding user behavior, pain points, and requirements within their natural environments.

title: 8. Support Techniques
body: To wrap up our series, we'll touch on support techniques that can enhance the effectiveness of your elicitation efforts. These include tools, templates, and software solutions designed to streamline the requirements gathering process. Finally, we'll summarize the key takeaways from our series on Requirements Elicitation, highlighting the critical role it plays in project success and providing guidance on applying these techniques in your own projects.

title: 2. Criteria for Good Requirements
body: In this part of the lecture, we will give you an overview of the most critical criteria to differentiate between high-quality and low-quality requirements. This includes consistency, correctness, completeness, agreement, unambigiuty, validity, and many more.

title: 3. Document Structure
body: What different types of documents, how can they be characterised, and what standards are most commonly used? These are all topics that we will discuss in this section. We will learn that every requirement document should contain specific contents that must be included.

title: 2. Goal Models
body:
Goal models are conceptual frameworks used to systematically represent and communicate the overarching objectives and desired outcomes of a system, project, or process. These models articulate the goals and intentions that stakeholders aim to achieve, providing a structured and organised representation.

Goal models help in aligning project objectives with stakeholder expectations, fostering a clear understanding of the purpose and direction of the initiative. They often utilise visual elements and hierarchical structures to depict the relationships and dependencies between different goals, contributing to effective communication and decision-making throughout the development or implementation.

title: 3. Use Cases
body:
Use cases are conceptual tools in software engineering that describe the interactions between end-users and a system to achieve specific functionalities or goals. These representations provide a detailed and structured narrative of how users interact with a system under various scenarios. Two differet concepts (use case diagrams
use case specification) exist and should be used in conjunction.

Use cases typically outline the steps involved, the system's responses, and any potential variations in user interactions. By focusing on user perspectives, use cases contribute to a comprehensive understanding of system behavior, aiding in requirements analysis, design, and communication among stakeholders

title: 2. AOM to CPN Mapping
body: The modelling process from Agent-Oriented Modeling (AOM) to Colored Petri Nets (CPN) involves translating the fundamental concepts of intelligent agents and their behaviours in AOM into a formal representation using CPNs. With their goals and actions, intelligent agents are identified and mapped to transitions in the CPN. Interactions and agent communication are represented through arcs and businesses, and system constraints are incorporated into the CPN structure. Colours may be used to denote different attributes. The resulting CPN model provides a formalised representation that allows for simulations, analysis, and verification of intelligent agents' dynamic behaviours and interactions within a system.

title: 3. Summary
body: Let's summarise what we have learned about documentation models in this lectue. We have mainly discussed formal specification techniques and Colored Petri Nets (incl. mapping from AOM). Be aware that additional methods might be better suited for your project. As part of the self-study content in the lecture slides that you can find below, you can learn about the four-variable models and NRL/SCR.

title: 2. Principles of Requirements Validation
body: The six principles of requirements validation are foundational guidelines crucial in ensuring the accuracy and integrity of software development specifications. It is important to involve the correct stakeholders, separate the identification and the correction of errors, validate from different points of view, adequately change documentation types, construct development artefacts and repeat the validation process.  Together, these principles serve as a rigorous framework for validating requirements, contributing to the reliability and success of software development endeavours.

title: 3. Validation Techniques
body: Validation techniques play a crucial role in ensuring the robustness of software requirements. Various reviews, such as commenting, inspections, and walkthroughs, involve detailed examination of requirements documentation to uncover inconsistencies and ambiguities. Commenting allows for collaborative feedback, while inspections involve a systematic analysis by a group of experts, and walkthroughs facilitate a guided exploration of the requirements. Supporting techniques like perspective-based reading provide different viewpoints for thorough assessment. Prototypes involving the creation of simplified software versions allow for practical validation of user interactions. Checklists serve as structured guides during reviews. Together, these techniques and supporting methods aim to enhance the precision and reliability of software requirements.

title: 2. Requirements Management Tools
body: Different tools exist that may be used for varying purposes. It may be possible to reuse tools from system development, or visualisation tools can support brainstorming sessions or depict processes and workflows.

title: 3. Introducing and Evaluating Tools
body: Before introducing tools, it is important to have existing processes that they can support. There may be different challenges while introducing tools, so it is important to consider them and discuss these implementations with all stakeholders. Evaluating these tools from different views is also vital.

title: Functional & Non-Functional Requirements
body:
In the realm of requirements engineering, it is crucial to distinguish between three categories of specifications: functional requirements, which outline the specific actions and behaviors a system should exhibit, and non-functional requirements, which define the quality attributes and constraints that underpin the system's overall performance and user experience.

Functional Requirements: Functional requirements specify the specific functions, features, and behaviors that a system or software must perform. They describe what the system should do, such as user interactions, data processing, and system responses. Functional requirements are typically stated in a clear and unambiguous manner and serve as the foundation for system design and development.

Non-Functional Requirements: Non-functional requirements define the quality attributes and constraints that the system must meet, but they do not describe specific functionality. Instead, they focus on aspects like performance, security, usability, scalability, and reliability. Non-functional requirements are essential for ensuring that the system meets user expectations and performs well under various conditions.

Constraints: Constraints in the context of requirements engineering are limitations or conditions that must be adhered to during the design, development, or operation of a system or software. These constraints can be imposed by various factors, including external regulations, technical limitations, budget constraints, or organizational policies.

title: 4. Summary
body: In summary, traceability emerges as a critical aspect, enabling a deep analysis and understanding of relationships among requirements, their sources, and development artefacts. It is a foundational element supporting various project activities, proving especially valuable during maintenance phases. While maintaining robust traceability poses challenges, its significance in enhancing overall project understanding and supporting activities for coherence and effectiveness cannot be overstated. Leveraging tools for traceability proves beneficial, providing a streamlined approach to navigating the project landscape's intricate connections.

title: 4. Data, Functional, and Behavioral Perspectives
body: Depending on which perspective (data, functional, or behavioural) you employ, you have to use different models—the data perspective centres on managing data within a system, detailing entities, attributes, and relationships. The functional perspective outlines the specific operations and functionalities a system must perform to meet user requirements. It delineates the "what" of the system's capabilities. In contrast, the behavioural perspective focuses on system responses, describing how it reacts to stimuli and changes in its environment.

title: 4. Summary
body:
To sum it up, the step of validating requirements in the requirements engineering process holds great importance as it acts as a critical checkpoint to ensure the quality, accuracy, and consistency of the gathered requirements. By employing various validation techniques, including reviews, inspections, and walkthroughs, potential issues, inconsistencies, and ambiguities are unearthed early in the process, mitigating the risk of costly errors during later stages of development.

This meticulous validation ensures that the requirements align with stakeholder expectations, adhere to best practices, and form a solid foundation for the subsequent phases of system development.

title: 4. Summary
body: During the RE process, various tools are accessible and categorised as specialised or general-purpose tools. Recognising that a sound process precedes the choice of tools is crucial, emphasising that the tool's suitability hinges on alignment with the strategy. Introducing new tools should undergo a pilot phase, as evaluating them is a time-consuming yet necessary endeavour for ensuring their efficacy and compatibility with the established RE framework.

title: 4. Syntactic Requirements Patterns and Summary
body: Syntactic requirements patterns is a technique that aims at avoiding mistakes and it is also known as requirement templates. These patterns provide a standardized methodology for expressing common types of requirements, reducing ambiguity, and fostering a systematic approach to documentation. Employing syntactic patterns contributes to an organized and comprehensible representation of requirements, ultimately resulting in a smoother communication among project stakeholders.

title: 1. Motivation of Requirements Engineering
body:
In software development, success hinges on a crucial yet often overlooked phase: gathering, documenting and managing requirements. This course aims to introduce you to Requirement Engineering (RE) and shed light on its significance for seasoned software engineers and aspiring IT students.

But why is Requirement Engineering so essential? As software engineers and informatics students, you will discover that the ability to elicit, document, and validate requirements effectively is the cornerstone of creating successful software products. It serves as the blueprint, the roadmap, and the compass that guides your development efforts. Through this course, you will not only grasp the technical aspects of RE but also recognise its broader implications for project management, communication, and customer satisfaction. 

In the first video, Prof. Dr. Benjamin Leiding will give you an introduction to what Requirements Engineering is and how Requirement Engineering equips you with a valuable skill set that is essential for success in the field of software development and IT.

title: 4. Survey Techniques
body: In this video, we cover the first elicitation technique: the survey technique. This in-depth examination highlights the importance of formulating questions that solicit meaningful and actionable responses and align with the overarching goals of your elicitation endeavour. As we traverse the landscape of survey techniques, you'll gain mastery over this valuable tool, enhancing your ability to navigate the complex terrain of requirements gathering with precision and insight.

title: 4. Document Templates and Summary
body: Lastly, we will discuss what document templates are and why it is essential to use them. Standard outlines fulfill many functions, such as simplifying the incorporation of new staff members, making selective reading possible,  and enabling automated verification of documents. Additionally, we will introduce some of the most widely used document templates to you.

title: 5. Agent-Oriented Modeling (AOM)
body:
Agent-Oriented Modeling (AOM) is a way of thinking about computer systems where we imagine them like a group of smart and independent agents. These agents can make decisions and work on their own goals. AOM is useful for complex systems where things can change a lot. 

It is an approach in software engineering that revolves around the concept of intelligent agents, representing autonomous entities capable of making decisions and interacting with their environment. In AOM, systems are conceptualized as collections of these intelligent agents, each having its own goals, capabilities, and behaviors. AOM focuses on modeling the interactions and collaborations among agents, emphasizing the decentralization of control and the autonomy of individual components. AOM contributes to a more flexible and adaptive system design, providing a framework for representing and analyzing the interactions of intelligent agents within a given environment.

title: 5. Course Summary
body: As we conclude the Requirements Engineering, we will briefly summarise the whole course, highlighting the most crucial insights and providing an overview of the key concepts covered. This summary is a culmination of exploring the intricacies of managing requirements and leveraging tools for effective project outcomes.

title: 1. Introduction and Traceability
body: Requirements traceability is akin to crafting a comprehensive life story for each project requirement. It's not just about understanding where a requirement starts; it's about following its entire journey. Think of it as creating a detailed timeline—from its inception and development through specifications to its deployment and utilisation in the real world. This meticulous tracing extends across various phases, capturing the continuous refinement and iteration throughout the project lifecycle. Essentially, it's like maintaining a detailed diary for each requirement, chronicling its growth, evolution, and impact on the project.

title: 1. Introduction and Managing Requirements
body: Imagine your project as a dynamic landscape where unforeseen shifts or additions may be necessary. This introduces the essence of change management—a systematic framework for accommodating modifications seamlessly. Beyond a mere response to evolving requirements, change management embodies a structured approach, contemplating the ripple effects of alterations across the project. It becomes the linchpin for preserving the project's agility amidst changing needs, fostering adaptability as an intrinsic quality.​​​​​

title: 1. Introduction and Textual Requirements Specification
body: Textual requirements specification is an approach that relies on natural language to detail system requirements, presenting a narrative that comprehensively outlines the desired functionalities. It has some essential advantages, such as flexibility, universality and comprehensibility. While this method allows for a nuanced and adaptable expression of requirements, it comes with the challenge of maintaining precision and clarity, necessitating careful articulation.

title: 1. Introduction
body: This video lays the foundation for our in-depth exploration of the Requirements Elicitation process. We confront the challenges surrounding the quest for precise and comprehensive information from stakeholders. Appreciating the intricacies of securing the correct data is paramount, as it forms the bedrock upon which the entire elicitation process stands. We thoroughly discuss the significance of transparent communication, the skilful management of expectations, and the profound repercussions of misunderstandings during the requirements-gathering phase. This initial step sets the tone for the entire series and underscores the critical importance of a meticulously executed elicitation process.

title: 5. Creativity Techniques
body: In this video, we embark on a journey into creativity methods such as mind mapping and dynamic brainstorming sessions. These techniques encourage stakeholders to venture beyond conventional thinking, tapping into the wellsprings of creativity to uncover latent needs and pioneer novel solutions.

title: 6. Document-Centric Techniques
body: In this video, we'll discuss how to effectively review and analyze documents to uncover implicit requirements, dependencies, and constraints. Documents often hold valuable information, and document-centric techniques allow us to extract requirements from existing documentation, such as user manuals, project reports, and contracts.

title: 1. Introduction and Documentation in General
body: As part of the RE process, documentation helps to translate abstract requirements into tangible and actionable directives. We will cover three perspectives on functional requirements: (1)The data perspective focuses on handling, storing, and manipulating data within a system. (2) The functional perspective is the core aspect of Functional Requirements, detailing the specific functionalities and operations that the system must perform to meet user needs. (3) The behavioural perspective provides a comprehensive view of the system's interactions with users and external entities, detailing the expected sequences of actions and reactions. Additionally, we will introduce the three different ways to document requirements (natural language, conceptual models and hybrid approach).

title: 1. Introduction and Models in General
body:
Documentation models are structured frameworks designed to systematically capture and communicate information about a system, process, or project. These models provide a standardised and organised format for representing various aspects, such as requirements, design, and functionality, offering enhanced clarity, consistency, and visualisation.

Documentation models facilitate stakeholder understanding, support analysis and design phases, and ensure requirement traceability by incorporating visual elements and structured representations. They also contribute to effective collaboration by providing a shared language and experience. Additionally, documentation models aid in documentation updates and maintenance, allowing for an accurate representation of the evolving state of the system throughout the development process. Overall, documentation models play a crucial role in enhancing communication, facilitating collaboration, and supporting the successful execution of projects.

title: 1. Introduction and Colored Petri Nets
body:
Colored Petri Nets (CPNs) is a formal modelling language used to represent and analyse complex systems, particularly those with concurrent processes and dynamic interactions. Petri Nets, in general, are graphical models that capture the flow of information, events, and actions within a system. What sets Colored Petri Nets apart is the use of colours to provide additional details on the tokens or elements in the system.

CPNs find applications in various fields, including computer science, software engineering, and systems biology, to model and analyse the behaviour of systems with concurrency, parallelism, and intricate interactions. The graphical nature of CPNs makes them particularly useful for visualising and understanding complex system dynamics.

title: 1. Introduction and Requirements Validation in General
displayTitle: 1. Introduction and Requirements Validation in General
body: In essence, requirements validation is the methodical examination of the master plan before the project commences, ensuring that the blueprint is comprehensive, error-free, and aligned with the overarching goals. Consider the validation process akin to scrutinising a detailed blueprint before the construction begins. In a more complicated scenario, let's say you're developing a cutting-edge software application. Before coding starts, you meticulously examine the requirements—the detailed instructions for the software's features and functions. Requirements validation involves ensuring these instructions are clear, logically sound, free of contradictions, and aligned with the desired outcomes. It's like running a diagnostic check to catch potential issues early on. This process is pivotal in preventing costly errors and ensuring that the final product meets the intended specifications, akin to quality assurance in manufacturing.

title: 1. Introduction and Tool Support in General
displayTitle: 1. Introduction and Tool Support in General
body: Tools are pivotal in modernising and optimising various processes, and Requirements Engineering (RE) is no exception. They facilitate capturing, analysing, documenting, and tracking requirements, contributing to a more streamlined and effective management process.
